trial_identification.studytitle: Can Egg Allergic Kids Eat Baked Egg? The CAKE Study.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Does Consumption of Baked Egg Hasten Development of Tolerance to Raw Egg in Children with Egg Allergy? - A Randomised, Controlled Trial.

interventions.interventions: Children with allergy to raw egg but able to tolerate baked egg will be recruited. Participants will remain on an egg free diet, and be randomised into one of two groups. The intervention group will be provided with egg containing baked products (muffin or fruit loaf). Each participant will be asked to consume around 3 serves of the study product each week (around 30g baked egg per week). After 6 months participants will cease the product and be re challenged to raw egg at 7 months.
interventions.comparator: The control group will be provided with egg free baked products (muffins or fruit loaf) that look and taste identical to the intervention products, but are egg free. Each participant will be asked to consume around 3 serves of the study product each week.

primaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and after 6 months of intervention.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Blood test to measure immune markers of tolerance development (serum specific IgE, IgG & IgG4, and cellular immune response profiles).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and at 6 months when intervention is ceased, and then again at 7 months prior to raw egg challenge.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: IgE mediated egg allergy Positive oral food challenge to pasteurised raw egg. Tolerance to baked egg.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Inability to provide informed consent. Non IgE mediated egg allergy. Children already consuming baked egg in their diet. FPIES, Wheat allergy. Children with any congenital or acquired disease or developmental disorder likely to affect the ablility to undergo an oral food challenge or to consume the intervention product.

trial_design.concealment: Upon consent children will be screened to ensure that they meet the inclusion criteria for the study. Children will be randomised to either treatment (baked egg) or control (egg free) and assigned a unique study ID. Allocation will involve contacting the holder of the randomisation schedule at a central administration site.
trial_design.sequence: A computer generated randomisation schedule using block design will be generated by statisticians independent of study conduct. Stratified will occur for the age of the child (<2 1/2 years and 2 1/2 to 5 years of age).

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Women's and Children's Health Research Institute
sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Women's and Children's Hospital 72 King William St North Adelaide South Australia 5006

fundingsource.fundingaddress: 72 King William St North Adelaide South Australia 5006

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Egg allergy is the most common food allergy in Australian children. Many children with egg allergy can tolerate baked products, but will fail an oral challenge to raw egg. The primary aim of this study is to determine whether allergy to raw egg is better resolved by regular consumption of baked egg (intervention group, baked egg exposure) compared with the standard practice of an egg free diet (control group, egg avoidance).
